item.title: Original GTA Designer Mike Dailly Praises Rockstar Delay After New GTA 6 Trailer
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/original-gta-designer-mike-dailly-praises-rockstar-delay-after-new-gta-6-trailer/1100-6531347/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Mike Dailly, one of the designers for the original GTA and a co-founding member of Rockstar North, said Rockstar made the right decision to delay GTA 6 after seeing the upcoming game's most recent trailer. Dailly made the comments on Bluesky, where he also praised the development team for not giving into greed and releasing a game that the studio knew could be improved.

Dailly said Rockstar undoubtedly knew GTA 6 would've sold exceptionally well even if it launched in a less-than-ideal state and called the studio's choice to delay it for extra polish "impressive."

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: GTA 6 (Grand Theft Auto VI) - Official Release Date Reveal | Trailer 2

"Now that's more like it," Dailly said in his post. "That environment is lovely, and things are moving much betterâ€¦ Even if they'd released it broken, it'd still have sold hugely. So it's even more impressive they took the decision to delay it. Kudos."

"Many of us are old enough to remember the debacle that Frontier: Elite II had on the PC, where greed got in the way," Dailly continued.

Frontier: Elite II launched in 1993, and while the space combat simulator received universal critical praise, it suffered from multiple, often game-breaking bugs on PC. Even those who remember it fondly recall how some of its essential features didn't work correctly, such as autopilot or rendering a planet.

Rockstar didn't publicly give a reason for GTA 6's delay after the announcement. However, as Dailly noted, the most recent version of Vice City looks crisper, and its inhabitants, from GTA 6's major characters to seemingly unimportant NPCs, move more naturally--in the in-game cutscenes, at least--compared to the first time Rockstar showed the game off.

GTA 6's new release date is May 26, 2026, for PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S. A PC version of GTA 6 has not been announced, but is expected at a later, unspecified date.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: GTA 6's Jason: Does He Even Lift, Bro? Here's How Much He Can Bench
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/gta-6s-jason-does-he-even-lift-bro-heres-how-much-he-can-bench/1100-6531346/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The new Grand Theft Auto VI trailer illuminated many new details about the highly anticipated open-world game, including the fact that main character Jason is absolutely shredded. The trailer opens with a shirtless Jason climbing down off the roof after doing some repairs. A close-up of Jason reveals he's got cannons for arms, a built back, and some impressive chest gains.

But how much can Jason bench? A sequence later in the trailer shows Jason on the beach, throwing up some impressive weight. In the trailer, we see Jason benching what appears to be 275lbs. Using weight plates from the amazingly fictional brand "GAINZ," we can see the outer-most plate is 25lbs. The inner ones look like 45-pound plates, so all of that weight combined with the bar (we are assuming it's the standard 45 pounds) and that comes to a mighty 275 pounds.

No matter what anyone says, a 275-pound bench is impressive. In gym and lifting culture, a bench press of 225 is the standard for what aspiring lifters hope to achieve. Given Jason's general buff-ness, I'm not surprised to see him putting up more, and having a well-rounded physique in general.

Also worth noting here is Jason's bench press form--it is very good. He takes the bar all the way down to his chest in a slow, controlled manner, making sure to not flare his arms out but keep the tight to his body. He also seems to not drop the weight in a straight line down to his chest. We could learn a thing or two from Jason's form.

Now, we can't say for sure what Jason's best bench is. It's possible Jason is not maxing out here but instead pumping for volume and muscle stamina. We do hear him grunt a little, but that doesn't mean he's struggling. He gets the weight up pretty easily, after all--earning the attention of a couple women nearby, too.

What I don't like to see here is Jason lifting all this weight without a spotter, or without a rack that has spotter arms. It's dangerous and unsafe to do this. But given Jason's line of work or robbing and shooting people as a drug-runner, it might be one of the safer activities he engages in.

Jason might be a gym bro, but we also see him in another sequence crashed out on the couch in the middle of the day with beers on his coffee table, so he clearly enjoys partying as well. Another scene shows Jason and Lucia at a club having a grand time. Remember, it's all about balance (minus the crime).

It's likely pumping out sets at the beach could be an activity in GTA 6, as Rockstar is known to allow players to do much of what they see in trailers for their games. Also, GTA 5 allowed players to hurl some weight around at an outdoor gym by the water as well, so it would be in keeping with tradition.

GTA 6 launches on May 26, 2026 for PS5 and Xbox Series X|S. That's a while to wait, so in the meantime, you can check out more than 150 new GTA 6 images in the gallery below. Beyond Jason and Lucia, GTA 6's story features a big cast of supporting characters. And in terms of places you'll visit, GTA 6 takes players to Vice City itself, along with the surrounding areas, like a park filled with wildlife.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: GTA 6 Preorders Are Not Yet Open
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/gta-6-preorders-are-not-yet-open/1100-6531344/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Grand Theft Auto VI now has a release date and a new trailer, so it's understandable to think that Rockstar Games might have opened preorders for the open-world crime game. For other games, a publisher might begin preorders after confirming a release date and posting a flashy trailer to capitalize on the hype. But no, that's not the case for GTA 6.

Although we now know GTA 6 is set for release on May 26, 2026 for PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S, retailers are not yet taking preorders. You should avoid any retailer currently trying to take your money to reserve the game, as it's likely a scam.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: GTA 6 (Grand Theft Auto VI) - Official Release Date Reveal | Trailer 2

Rest assured, when Rockstar announces preorder details for GTA 6, we'll report back with all the details. In addition to a standard version, it's expected Rockstar will offer premium-edition versions of the game, just like it did with GTA 5.

For comparison, preorders for GTA 5 opened in November 2012, which was after the first trailer arrived in November 2011. GTA 6, meanwhile, has already had two trailers, the first of which was released in December 2023; the second debuted on May 6, 2025.

In addition as to when GTA 6 preorders will open, another major unanswered question is how much GTA 6 might cost. With some AAA games jumping from $70 to $80, many are wondering if GTA 6 will follow suit or even potentially go higher, like $100, as some believe might happen. GTA 5 launched in 2013 priced at $60; that's about $80 in 2025 with inflation factored in.

Take-Two, many might recall, was the first major publisher to raise prices for AAA games from $60 to $70 with NBA 2K21. Take-Two defended the price hike and said it was generally accepted by fans.

GTA 6 is set in Vice City, which is a stand-in for Miami. The game also takes players to the surrounding area in the fictional state of Leonida, which is inspired by Florida. Beyond main characters Jason and Lucia, players will meet a variety of other supporting characters, including a conspiracy theorist.

While we wait for more information about GTA 6, you can check out 150+ screenshots from the game in the gallery below.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Get This Fun Swashbuckling Game And 7 Others For Just $12 At Humble This Month
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/get-this-fun-swashbuckling-game-and-7-others-for-just-12-at-humble-this-month/1100-6531241/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The May 2025 lineup of PC games for Humble Choice subscribers has been revealed, and this month, you can look forward to an action game that feels like it came straight out of the PS2 era, spine-tingling horror, and a fantastic game starring a motley crew of pirates.

In case you've missed out on it, Humble Choice is a $12 monthly subscription service that offers a monthly batch of PC games that are yours to keep forever, even if you decide to cancel your membership. There are other perks to this membership as well, including exclusive discounts at the Humble store and access to the Humble Vault--an additional rotating library of games that's only available to members.

Humble Choice May 2025 Games

  • The Thaumarturge: Deluxe Edition
  • Amnesia: The Bunker
  • Evil West
  • Shadow Gambit: The Cursed Crew
  • Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes
  • Star Wars: Bounty Hunter
  • Ultros
  • Corpse Keeper

One of the big highlights here is Shadow Gambit: The Cursed Crew, a delightful blend of stealth and strategy, infused with a swashbuckling spirit. A genuine treat for anyone who enjoys stealth and meticulously planning their next move, the game was sadly the final title developed by Mimimi, as the studio shut down several weeks later. It's a genuinely fun gem of a game, and it was one of GameSpot's personal faves in 2023.

A few of the other interesting games available this month include the superb horror game Amnesia: The Bunker, trippy metroidvania Ultros, and the action-packed Evil West. It won't blow your socks off, but Evil West is still an enjoyable Western romp full of steampunk influences, thrilling combat, and plenty of supernatural goons to explosively punch into a puddle of blood and organs.

As a reminder, all these games are available at no additional to Humble Choice members as part of their $12/month subscription. You can sign up now and gain immediate access to them all, and they're yours to download and keep forever. You'll also get all the other membership perks, including the Humble Vault--which is a rotating library of even more games exclusive to members--and special Humble Store discounts. Additionally, 5% of every Humble Choice membership is donated to charity, and proceeds this month will go to Comic Relief USA's Red Nose Day.

You can also check out a few more bundle deals at Humble, including this collection of every XCOM game on PC for just $10.

Humble Game Bundle Deals

  • XCOM Complete Bundle -- 17 items for $10
  • Return to metroidvania Bundle -- 8 items for $14
  • Doom and Wolfenstein Mayhem Bundle -- 15 items for $28
  • Tycoon Titans Bundle -- 10 items for $13
  • Play for miracles with Twin Sails Bundle -- 31 items for $20
Darryn Bonthuys on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Destiny 2 Fate Saga Roadmap Revealed Into 2026
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/destiny-2-fate-saga-roadmap-revealed-into-2026/1100-6531343/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Bungie has revealed its plans for the next long story arc for Destiny 2. The developers have revealed a "multi-year saga" in the form of the Fate Saga. The beginning of this new chapter of Destiny's story, there will be four expansions to start us off known as the Year of Prophecy.

Starting on July 15, 2025 with The Edge of Fate, players will journey to the mysterious planetoid Kepler and find more questions than answers about the universe at large. After that on December 2, 2025, we will get the expansion Renegades. As per Bungie's new content roadmap plans, there will now be two expansions a year going forward. So now with more densely-packed expansions than what players have seen with Episodes and less waiting time, more content will be seen quickly rather than the 1-2 year gap between expansions as before.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Destiny 2: Renegades | Teaser Trailer

In between each expansion there will also be what Bungie is dubbing "Major Updates," with overhauls to the sandbox, new events, modifier and challenge updates, new gear and Artifact mods, and more. On September 9, 2025, the first major update of the Season of Reclamation, titled Ash & Iron, will release. Then, as part of Renegades and the Season of Lawless, the Shadow & Order update will drop on March 3, 2026. The most-enticing detail here is that each major update will not cost anything, nor will it be vaulted or taken away. Major updates will be free to all Destiny 2 players, and the content they bring will always be part of the game at large. These updates will be approximately the size of the Into the Light seasonal update with lots of events and new content to find.

That's not all, as we already have names for the next expansions for the Year of Prophecy going into 2026 as well. Shattered Cycle will launch in Summer 2026. Finally, in Winter 2026 will be the finale of the Year of Prophecy, The Alchemist.

Bungie have said they promise to show lots of new destinations, new gameplay features, and even some returning favorites. Included among all of the massive updates coming starting this July is a customizable difficulty for destinations, which we detail in this article here.

Alex Hadzaman on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
